post_text:
Nashville, our county's census response rate is only 63.7% as the October deadline to respond nears.

Why does your participation matter? Census numbers impact our city's children and funds vital programs and services like Head Start and special education.

Please respond online today -- It only takes a few minutes. https://my2020census.gov

And, if you want to look at the national response rate map yourself, you can find the link here: https://2020census.gov/en/response-rates/self-response.html

post_text:
From Dr. Battle, in a column published today:

"Some students with exceptional needs started returning to our school buildings this week, and if Nashville‚Äôs public health trends keep moving in the right direction, we‚Äôll start bringing our youngest students in Pre-K through second grade back to our elementary schools after fall break.

Then we‚Äôll expand to higher grades step by step ‚Äì grades 3-4, then middle school, then high school ‚Äì with a phased-in approach that will allow us to monitor progress, make adjustments, and acclimate both students and staff to this new environment in a steady, efficient, and safe manner.

For parents, there are no wrong answers to the survey. If you want your children back in the classroom, we look forward to seeing them in schools where we have provided personal protective equipment (PPE), masks, sanitizer, and cleaning supplies to limit the spread of COVID-19."

https://www.tennessean.com/story/opinion/2020/09/10/nashville-public-schools-provide-families-safe-equitable-options/5768913002/
shared_text:
TENNESSEAN.COM

Are you a new graduate or someone looking to make a career switch? Come teach with us!

The Tennessee Department of Education is temporarily relaxing the department‚Äôs internal requirements and standard waivers for eligible, interested future teachers.

‚ÄúIn times of local and national crises, our schools, our teachers, and our support teams have continued to serve students. Our physical school buildings may be quieter right now, but high-quality education is still being provided to our students across the city,‚Äù said Chris Barnes, chief of human resources.

https://www.mnps.org/blog/2020/9/9/state-licensure-requirements-for-teachers-temporarily-relaxed

post_text:
Families, our schools will now offer no-cost breakfast and lunch to all children 18 and under based on newly released federal guidelines.

The district is able to do this because of a new federal waiver in place until December 31. Because these waivers will eventually end, it is important that students who do not attend a Community Eligibility Program school should complete the Free and Reduced Lunch application as soon as possible so, if approved, they will continue to receive no-cost meals once the waivers end.

‚ÄúNutritious meals are essential to effective learning, growth, and development,‚Äù said Dr. Adrienne Battle, Director of Metro Schools. ‚ÄúWe are grateful that the USDA has removed barriers to accessing meals to allow more students and children throughout Nashville to more easily receive breakfast and lunch.‚Äù

To read the full announcement visit https://news.mnps.org/all-mnps-breakfast-and-lunch-will-be-no-cost-to-families/

You also can find the announcement, more information about our meals and nutrition program, and support application links on https://www.mnps.org/nutrition

post_text:
Families, have you taken a look at the Student-Parent Handbook and submitted the opt-out forms? The forms deadline is this Friday, Sept. 4.

It's all online and it provides important information on student rights, discipline rules and procedures, and family resources.

The handbook also provides information on important permissions your school needs to allow your child access to certain programs and equipment, or related to the information you wish to have publicly released about your child. It is important guardians review and respond to these Family Permissions.

The online permissions portal is new, and at launch, we had some technical difficulties that have been identified and corrected. If you have any trouble submitting the forms, reach out to your student's school, or the Family Information Center at 615-259-INFO.

A special note for families of high school students: The military recruitment opt-out form cannot be completed online.
Link to handbook: https://www.mnps.org/handbook

Congratulations to Nashville School of the Arts senior Madison Eddins, whose art work honoring the women's suffrage movement will be on exhibit in front of the White House.

Madison's work was submitted as part of a national competition and selected by the First Lady. The exhibit is called "Building the Movement: America‚Äôs Youth Celebrate 100 Years of Women‚Äôs Suffrage."

PS: The women portrayed in Madison's drawing are Ida B. Wells, Sue Shelton White, and J. Frankie Pierce, whom she says she learned about in U.S. history class.

https://www.newschannel5.com/news/flotus-chooses-nashville-teen-to-represent-tennessee-in-national-womens-suffrage-art-exhibit

Friends of NSA

Metro Nashville Public Schools extends a sincere thank you to Amy Frogge & Jill Speering, whose time on the Board of Education has ended, for being tireless champions for Nashville's children.

Our schools and staff have been well-served by you both.
text:
Metro Nashville Public Schools extends a sincere thank you to Amy Frogge & Jill Speering, whose time on the Board of Education has ended, for being tireless champions for Nashville's children.

Our schools and staff have been well-served by you both.

Navigators will connect students to resources and supports systems. You will hear more about this from your schools.

You can read more about student and family support in the Virtual Learning Parent Playbook, https://www.mnps.org/playbook-sel

If you are in search of community support, please also visit the MNPS Healthy Youth Community Resource Guide https://www.mnps.org/community-resource-guide

Here‚Äôs a great, short 17-minute video that serves as both a study break and a lesson in the Energy of Dance ‚Äì it shows students the connection between energy and movement and how science can be found in the most creative places. https://youtu.be/kbjyRqGVYmc

This video comes from our community partners at OZ Arts, who launched OZ Arts STEAM Fusion, a collection of educational videos that highlight science, technology, engineering, arts and math content like the solar system, the scientific method and more, to help keep all students engaged and learning remotely plus help students explore the cross-discipline value of the arts

You can check out the entire video library at https://www.ozartsnashville.org/steam-fusion/ And, if you‚Äôre a teacher, there‚Äôs an educator guide for each video available for download.

OZ Arts Nashville

post_text:
Good morning. As schools begin MAP testing for grades K-9, some tips for families:

1. Minimize distractions as much as possible
2. Provide a quiet testing environment
3. Allow the teacher/proctor to open the session first
4. Log in at test.mapnwea.org (You may need to disable the pop-up blocker.)
5. Make sure you or your student has joined the
Teams meeting with the teacher/proctor
6. Follow any additional instructions from the
teacher/proctor.

Remember, there's a practice test at https://practice.mapnwea.org (Username: grow, Password: grow)

And, as a reminder: These scores will be used to support your child and help us identify learning loss due to the extended school closure this past spring. Students cannot pass or fail. Test results will not affect grades and will not be used for academic magnet eligibility. The MAP scores from the 2019-20 school year also will be used for academic magnet eligibility.

PRACTICE.MAPNWEA.ORG
Test Player

post_text:
Davidson County, only 60% of us have filled out our 2020 Census. If you have not already done so, you can expect a 2020 Census worker (with a government ID) to knock on your door. But, you can still submit your census online at https://my2020census.gov

This year, we have one less month to answer our census. The deadline is now September 30 - which potentially means an undercount. How does that affect our schools? Our schools, and city, receive federal dollars for everything from meals to educational programs based on the official census count. Every resident is required to answer the census, and it is confidential.

If also can respond on the telephone:
* 844-330-2020 (English)
* 844-468-2020 (Spanish)
* 844-416-2020 (Arabic)

Want to see response rates in other counties and across the country? https://2020census.gov/en/response-rates.html
How to identify a census field representative: https://www.census.gov/about/regions/denver/contact/identify.html

September 4 deadline: Families you can now fill out your student‚Äôs annual permissions and opt-out forms online.
Visit www.mnps.org/handbook to fill out the forms and submit them electronically or you can download and print them and return them to your school.

The forms are available in English, Arabic, Burmese, Kurdish, Nepali, Somali and Spanish.

As a reminder, high school students must complete and return the military recruitment opt-out form in-person. This form cannot be completed online.

If you have any questions, please contact your school or the Family Information Center at 615-259-INFO.

post_text:
The First Day of School looked so different than every other one before. For some of us, the technology trouble started us off with overwhelm and frustration. But, as we start this year virtually, lets celebrate the educators, staff and families who are working together with dedication and great hope for our students and community.

We are happy to be back and we look forward to partnering with you to make this year a spectacular one of growth and joy for our students.

Students, welcome back, see you tomorrow and we can't wait to be back in school with you again.

post_text:
An update on sports: On advice of the Metropolitan Public Health Department, Metro Schools will delay interscholastic high school sports competitions until at least Labor Day. Games/competitions shall not occur until at least September 8, 2020.

At this point, every fall sport may continue conditioning and non-contact skills workouts as they have been the past few weeks consistent with the MNPS Interscholastic Sports Activities Guide.
The MNPS Interscholastic Sports Activities Guide continues to be in effect for the rest of this week and the week of August 3 through August 7.

post_text: "Starting Kindergarten in a virtual setting is scary and overwhelming, but this is what teachers do - we take the situation that we're given, we take what we have and we make it work. We are going to do everything we can to make this the best experience possible for our students and for our families and for each other because that's what we do. We do what is best and what is right for our kids." - Greg Smedley-Warren, a Kindergarten teacher at J.E. Moss Elementary School, offering a welcome back message to his students and to us all.

post_text:
A survey was emailed yesterday to MNPS families to:
* make sure the district has the most updated contact information for all our families.
* get a general idea of which option families may select between continued virtual and in-person instruction - after it is safe enough to open our school buildings again. Note: This is not your final decision. Families will have additional opportunities to update their selection of continuing virtual or selecting in-person instruction for their student(s).
* make sure we know which students still need access to a device or internet hotspot. (Your schools are handling the delivery of devices.)
NOTE: Charter Schools are not included in the this survey.

text:
A survey was emailed yesterday to MNPS families to:
* make sure the district has the most updated contact information for all our families.
* get a general idea of which option families may select between continued virtual and in-person instruction - after it is safe enough to open our school buildings again. Note: This is not your final decision. Families will have additional opportunities to update their selection of continuing virtual or selecting in-person instruction for their student(s).
* make sure we know which students still need access to a device or internet hotspot. (Your schools are handling the delivery of devices.)
NOTE: Charter Schools are not included in the this survey.

If you have not already responded to the survey, please do so. There‚Äôs a link on the Back to School page, https://www.mnps.org/backtoschool
And here is a direct link: https://www.research.net/r/MNPSpreferencesurvey

post_text:
‚ùì What devices are best for virtual learning?
üíª MNPS will use the learning system Schoology for most virtual learning activities in K-12 courses. Schoology works on most devices with web capabilities. The preferred browser is Chrome. Any device - Chromebook, iOS, or Windows laptops such as Dell or Surface - with an internet connection will allow students to access Schoology. However, Android Fire tablets are discouraged from being used. For more information, visit Schoology‚Äôs website.
https://support.schoology.com/hc/en-us/articles/201002153-System-Requirements

For Flipgrid, which Pre-K students will use, https://help.flipgrid.com/hc/en-us/articles/360004051153-Minimum-Device-Requirements

Families also can find information, and more, on https://www.mnps.org/digitaltools and the FAQ section of https://www.mnps.org/backtoschool

Schools will be in touch with families to find out if students need devices or hotspots, so please keep an eye out for communication from your school.

post_text:
‚ùì Will students use the Florida Virtual School curriculum all school year?
üíª Yes. MNPS K-12 students will use the Florida Virtual School curriculum for online classes as well as for in-person classes when it is safe to return. That way, students - whether working at home or in school - will learn at the same pace as their peers and in such a way that they can move between a virtual and an in-person class environment if the COVID-19 pandemic requires change throughout the year.
üñç Information for Pre-K families is forthcoming.

This information, and more, is on the MNPS Back to School page: https://www.mnps.org/backtoschool

post_text:
Families, staff and community, we have received hundreds of questions and we are gathering answers. We will be sharing information on our social media channels a lot. And, we‚Äôll also be updating the Back to School webpage. Plus, our staff is hard at work planning informational videos, online meetings and blog posts to help plan the start of our children‚Äôs school year. We‚Äôre all in this together. Up first today: Curriculum.

‚ùìWhat learning platform will my student use?
üìöGrades K-12 will use Schoology and Pre-K will use Flipgrid.
Learn more about these learning systems: https://www.mnps.org/digitaltools

üíª Parents, you will need an access code from one of your child‚Äôs teachers to create a Schoology account to access your student‚Äôs work and activity. Once you create an account, you can add another student in the same account, but you‚Äôll need to get a new code from one of your other child‚Äôs teachers if he or she attends a different school.

For Flipgrid, students will use their MNPS email and password to log in. Families can create a free educator account with a personal email address.

post_text:
Need to register your child for MNPS Kindergarten for the 2020-21 school year? You can do it quickly and safely online or, or if you need in-person help, make an appointment at a district Enrollment Center. More details, including the online registration web link: https://mnps.org/register-for-school

Note: Even if your child attended MNPS Pre-K during the 2019-20 school year, you still need to register your child for kindergarten.

Families who need a translator, or speak a language other than English at home, can register new students by appointment at the English Learners office. Contact: (615) 259-8608 or email ELreg@mnps.org.

If you have any questions, please contact the MNPS Family Information Center at (615) 259-INFO (4636).

MNPS Pre-K

New MNPS students can register for school using our convenient online portal or by appointment.

If you need in-person help you can make an appointment at an MNPS Enrollment Center. We have plexiglass between staff and visitors and masks and temperature checks are required.

Families who need a translator, or speak a language other than English at home, can register by appointment at the English Learners office: (615) 259-8608 or email ELreg@mnps.org.

If your child was in MNPS Pre-K last year, and moving up to Kindergarten, they must also go through the registration process.

More registration information: https://www.mnps.org/register-for-school

post_text:
Dr. Adrienne Battle has appointed Dr. Mason Bellamy to serve as the Chief of Academics and Schools for MNPS. A veteran educator and administrator in the Clarksville-Montgomery County School System, Dr. Bellamy will oversee the academic and school support programs for Metro Schools.

‚ÄúThe Chief of Academics and Schools is going to play a critical role in our district as we embark upon the most unique and challenging school year the district has ever faced,‚Äù said Dr. Battle. ‚ÄúDr. Bellamy brings a new perspective to MNPS - but with a deep understanding of operating a large school district in the Tennessee environment. His leadership experience at every level of CMCSS will serve Nashville and Davidson County's students and families well as we seek to achieve and enhance academic excellence at every school through strong curriculum and school support.‚Äù

Join us in warmly welcoming Dr. Bellamy, and learn more about him at: https://news.mnps.org/mason-bellamy-appointed-to-serve-as-chief-of-academics-and-schools-for-mnps/

Class of 2020 Graduates, unfortunately, with the recent spike in COVID-19 cases and the city‚Äôs return to modified Phase 2, we cannot responsibly and safely host the type of meaningful in-person graduation ceremonies that you, your families, and our staff were hoping to have.

We are sorry social distancing and stay-at-home orders made it difficult, or impossible, to enjoy the senior traditions you were looking forward to. And, know that our hearts are with you all as we wish you health, joy, and success. üéìüíô

Your schools will be in touch about diploma pickup. If you haven‚Äôt already seen it, please watch the virtual graduation video that celebrates the MNPS Class of 2020, https://www.mnps.org/graduation2020

post_text:
Students and Families, Metro Schools will provide information about the upcoming school year at 1 p.m. Thursday, July 9, which you can watch on the Metro Nashville Network. For more information:

www.mnps.org/blog/2020/7/6/back-to-school-announcement-coming-july-9

‚ÄúI understand the uncertainty of this situation can be frustrating and cause anxiety,‚Äù Dr. Battle wrote in an email to families today. ‚ÄúWe might not have the answer to every conceivable question by Thursday, because we‚Äôre still learning about the impact and the ramifications of the COVID-19 pandemic every day. But we promise to tell you what we know and to be transparent about the opportunities we have and the challenges we face in the year ahead. We know how much you count on MNPS, and we don‚Äôt take that lightly. Thank you for the trust you place in us every day, year after year. We consider it a privilege to serve you, and we look forward to navigating this unique school year with you.‚Äù

Summer resources: Families with children ages 0 to 8 can sign up for free text messages from Bright by Text, in partnership with the United Way of Greater Nashville, that sends you information about local resources like the health department, library; learning content from partners like PBS and Vroom; and extended learning, literacy and tips for fun activities.

Families, as we plan for Back to School, if your student does not need school bus transportation services for the 2020-21 school year, please fill out the Decline Student Transportation form. The form and more info on https://www.mnps.org/transportation
* Complete one form per student.
* This request does not apply to students attending choice schools or charter schools.
* This request does not apply to students who take WeGo transit.
* You will need to know your student‚Äôs ID number.
If you do not know the Student ID number, contact the Family Information Center at 615-259-INFO or FamilyInfo@mnps.org

post_text:
Hello, MNPS. Here's an update on the 2020-21 school year: When school starts Aug. 4, MNPS students will have two options for the first semester: in-person or virtual learning.

Students who choose virtual learning will still be tied to the school they would have attended if they were going in person. In-person extracurricular options, including sports, will still be an option for students who chose a virtual classroom. Making a decision on a semester basis will allow schools to adequately staff both the in-person and virtual programs, develop seating assignments to maximize social distancing, and ensure consistency with accountability measures.

Read more, and watch Dr. Battle‚Äôs presentation to the School Board: https://www.mnps.org/blog/2020/6/26/2020-21-school-year-will-offer-in-person-and-virtual-learning-options

Apply for a Student Identification Number

post_text:
The students in our schools belong to families who represent 144 countries of origin and 132 languages. Some are refugees who have fled persecution and oppression to make Nashville home. On the observance of World Refugee Day, we offer gratitude for the resilient, wonderful students, colleagues, neighbors and friends who offer us living examples of what hope and hard work for a better future looks like.

Pictured, Joseph Rukesha, bilingual tutor for MNPS, and his wife Esther Nyirankundwa. He offers this about his experience: ‚ÄúI'm from the Democratic Republic of the Congo DRC. We were refugees in the Republic of Uganda in a refugee camp called Kyaka II for 11 years. God blessed us by opening doors for me and my family to be resettled in the USA in September 2015. I'm happy today remembering the experience of the hardship life we struggled, and today on this occasion of the World Refugee Day, we celebrate life changing.‚Äù

#withrefugees
#worldrefugeeday2020

post_text: The English Learners Registration and Assessment Center is opening July 6. Parents in households where a language other than English is spoken at home should call (615) 259-8608 or email ELreg@mnps.org for a registration appointment. Due to COVID-19, we cannot accept walk-ins and we ask that visitors wear masks and only one guardian per family come to the office for registration.

post_text:
As we celebrate freedom and liberation today on the 155th Juneteenth, let us work together toward justice and equity for all.

‚ÄúEducation is not immune from injustice or inequity. Far too often we see it all around us. We continue to strive for a more equitable public school system in which, no matter what zip code a child is born into, he or she will have access to the same high-quality learning environments as students across town. We haven‚Äôt gotten there yet, and we aren‚Äôt going to get there as quickly as any of us would like. But we have to keep pushing ourselves toward the goal line.‚Äù ‚Äî Dr. Adrienne Battle.

Dr. Battle's full message: https://bit.ly/2YgeMIk

post_text: Today, the U.S. Supreme Court provided extended protection to millions of immigrants in the United Stated under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which officially began accepting applications on August 15, 2012. We are so thankful that the many brave Dreamers among our students, graduates and staff have been given hope. Having come to Nashville for a better life and more opportunity, they should be able to pursue their dreams here without fear. #HomeisHere #Dreamers

post_text:
Update on report cards and Class of 2020 diplomas: Check the mailbox for end of year report cards, or log in and check grades in the MNPS Family Portal. https://www.mnps.org/familyportal

IEP progress reports for students with an individualized education program will be in the mail next week. Plus, Class of 2020 graduates will get information from their schools about picking up diplomas.

Questions, or if you have not received your documents by the end of next week, contact the Family Information Center, 615-259-INFO. If you never have logged into the Family Portal and need an activation key, the Family Info Center can help.

post_text:
Class of 2020 graduates - and all the people who love them - join us at 7 p.m. Saturday June 20 to watch the virtual graduation ceremony on NewsChannel 5 Nashville. The special features photos, video, speeches and a few celebrity cameos.

And, about the possibility of future in-person ceremonies, Dr. Adrienne Battle says: ‚ÄúWhile I‚Äôm pleased we were able to put the virtual ceremony together, I don‚Äôt want it to be the last word on your graduation. Your high schools‚Äô principals are planning for in-person ceremonies in late July as we continue to monitor public health data. Assuming Nashville continues to make progress and moves into the final phases of reopening the city, I look forward to celebrating with you in a month or so.‚Äù

Also, please check your inbox for information on free college counseling available to the Class of 2020 from Persist Nashville.

post_text:
Big news: Shasta Charlton, an Alternative Energy, Agriscience & Greenhouse Management teacher & Robotics Club coach at Whites Creek HS has been selected among thousands of eligible teachers as one of 10 Amazon Future Engineer Teacher of the Year Award recipients. She receives a prize package valued at over $50,000, which includes school supplies, tablets and other essentials.

‚ÄúI cannot thank Amazon enough for choosing Whites Creek High School as one of the recipients for the robotics grant,‚Äù Charlton said. ‚ÄúThis program has sparked an excitement for engineering & technology that didn‚Äôt exist at our school. I am beyond honored to have been selected as teacher of the year. I will continue to encourage my students to explore new paths and challenge themselves to innovate and create the world‚Äôs next leading technology.‚Äù

Charlton learned of the prize during a surprise video conference call. You can watch the video call on Twitter: https://twitter.com/WCHS_Davis/status/1272930949353873409

The Academies of Nashville #futureengineer #TeamMNPS

post_text:
Food Support: Families whose children qualify for free or reduced lunch at school may be eligible for assistance that provides additional money for food. (Parents who currently receive SNAP or TANF benefits do not need to apply.) Application link: https://tdhs.service-now.com/relief?id=relief_registration

Questions or need help with the application? Call the Tennessee Department of Human Services hotline at 1-833-496-0661 and select option 3.

More details from the state Department of Human Services: https://www.tn.gov/humanservices/news/2020/6/15/financial-assistance-available-for-families-that-qualify-for-free-and-reduced-school-lunches-.html

MNPS continues to provide meals for students and food boxes for families at several locations. Please visit https://www.mnps.org/covid19 for times and locations.

MNPS workers distributed meals for students in bags printed with important 2020 Census information in various languages to encourage everyone in our community to get counted. It makes a difference in the services and educational tools we offer our students.

Have you responded to the 2020 Census yet? It‚Äôs not too late! It's quick and easy. Online at https://my2020census.gov

or call (844) 330-2020.

The bags were made possible by a grant from the State of Tennessee Complete Count Grant Program.

post_text:
Metro Schools proudly announces a dynamic group of new school principals.

‚ÄúGreat principals aren‚Äôt just administrators, they are leaders who set the climate and culture to create an excellent learning environment and place to work,‚Äù said Dr. Adrienne Battle, Director of Schools.

They are:

Cumberland Elementary School - Jeresther Thorpe-Page (formerly Interim Principal)

Haynes Middle School* - Roderick Webb

Jere Baxter Middle School* - Kisha Stinson-Cox

Jones Paideia Elementary School* - Myra Taylor

Oliver Middle School - Hawaya Wilson (formerly Interim Principal)

Percy Priest Elementary School - Russell Young

Waverly Belmont Elementary School - Robin Shumate

Whites Creek High School - Brian J. Mells

*Haynes Middle, Jere Baxter Middle, and Jones Paideia Elementary are all schools that have recently undergone consolidations as part of the Metro Schools ReimaginED initiative.

For more on each principal, please visit http://news.mnps.org/mnps-announces-new-school-leadership-appointments/

post_text:
Mayor John Cooper's commitment of $24 million of Metro‚Äôs CARES Act funds to provide devices for our students is a massive step forward for equity and toward bridging the digital divide.

We need equitable access for our students so everyone can learn in any setting. It is past time that our city and our school district provide a device for every student, and now we are moving much closer to reaching that goal. We will maintain our focus on equity by making sure that we prioritize areas of the city and students who have the greatest need during our deployment of devices ‚Äì and then work to fill the need for all students.

Mayor Cooper, thank you for working alongside Director of Schools Dr. Adrienne Battle to make our students, their learning and their growth a priority. Because when our students grow, our city grows, too. They are our future, and as we saw with the march that many of them led and participated in last Thursday, they are our present, too.

MNPS choir students sing out beautifully in ‚ÄúWe are Nashville‚Äù - a collaboration with the Nashville Symphony. Can you spot your student?

Vocalists were from the following schools and programs: Waverly-Belmont Elementary (Alice Walle, Choir Instructor); Granbery Elementary (Kathryn Affainie, Choir Instructor), Glendale Spanish Immersion Elementary School (Rita Black, Choir Instructor); Isaiah T. Creswell Middle School of the Arts (Nita Smith, Choir Instructor), Thomas Edison Elementary (Christopher Blackmon/Marie Morris, Choir Instructors), Dan Mills Elementary (Kim Folsom) and the Voices of Vision Community Children‚Äôs Choir led by MNPS Elementary Coach Franklin Willis.

The performance also includes several talented middle and high school instrumentalists from MNPS and surrounding counties, performing with the Nashville Symphony. The students are a part of the Symphony‚Äôs Accelerando Initiative.

‚ÄúWe are Nashville‚Äù words and music by Bryson Finney and Christopher Blackmon, Orchestral Arrangement by Jerry Lackey.

Music Makes Us

Community, we are changing the menus for our meal pick up offerings to include familiar items like chicken tenders, hamburgers and grilled cheese sandwiches. They are fully cooked, but it may be preferable to heat before eating. Heating instructions will be provided with the meals.

Metro Schools will keep offering this meal service for children 18 and under, Mondays through Fridays throughout the summer at several school locations and bus stops throughout Davidson County.

Please check https://bit.ly/MNPSResourcesMap for dates, times and locations for meal options.

This map, and meals information as a PDF download, is available in several languages at: https://www.mnps.org/covid19

‚ÄúMy fondest memory is having teammates to make me better in class and on the court/field and bonding with all of them like family.‚Äù ‚Äî Kalailah Coleman, Pearl-Cohn Entertainment Magnet High School üéì

‚ÄúI feel sad and anxious because there were more memories to be made and things to experience. Nonetheless, I am thankful and grateful for everything that has happened.‚Äù ‚Äì Diana Nguyen, Hillwood High School üéì

Summer Experience: Students, in current grades 3 to 11, can keep the borrowed laptop to participate in online summer learning experiences the district will launch in June. (More details coming soon).

post_text:
MNPS is proposing several changes to improve academic outcomes for all students, including the consolidation of some schools. This is being done as part of the Metro Schools ReimaginED initiative that is exploring new systems of supports, rebranded and strengthened academic pathways, and a focus on improving climate and culture at schools across every school and every cluster.
Please note this proposal, which will be voted on by the Board of Education on May 19, includes the closure of the Cohn Learning Center program but does not affect the Cohn School Building, which will continue to house several MNPS and community programs regardless, including the Virtual School. For information and upcoming community meetings, please visit: https://www.mnps.org/blog/reimagined-proposal-seeks-to-consolidate-schools-to-streamline-and-better-support-all-students

post_text:
Alumni from Glencliff, Hume-Fogg and Martin Luther King, Jr. have just graduated from Lipcomb University in the first cohort of the Pionero Scholars program and they will begin teaching in Metro Schools. The program‚Äôs goal is to bring more educators of diverse backgrounds into our classrooms.

‚ÄúI want my (future) students to be self-confident in their abilities,‚Äù said Alondra Pi√±a, a Glencliff High School graduate and new middle school English teacher. ‚ÄúThat is one of the biggest things I learned as a student. I really want them to see a challenge and believe in themselves and believe they can do it too, no matter their background.‚Äù

Welcome to #TeamMNPS!
shared_text:
LIPSCOMB.EDU
From the Graduation Files 2020: Pionero program works to bridge the culture gap between students and teachers

Good morning, all. Students taking AP classes have exams this week. Today‚Äôs exams are for Physics C: Mechanics; Physics C, Electricity and Magnetism; and U.S. Government and Politics.

Tomorrow: Latin; Calculus AB, Calculus BC and Human Geography

Students, remember to check in 30 minutes before your exam. Exam walkthrough video: https://youtu.be/qHZ2zpqlZNE

For the whole schedule: https://apcoronavirusupdates.collegeboard.org/students/taking-ap-exams/ap-exam-schedule

Main AP exam information page: https://apcoronavirusupdates.collegeboard.org/students

Note: Students may also choose to not take the AP exam this year given the circumstances. Any test fees already paid will be reimbursed. More information on: https://www.mnps.org/seniors

post_text:
Congratulations to the dedicated #TeamMNPS teachers, principals and support staff who today are awarded with recognition for representing the district spirit and commitment to students. Thank you for all you do every day.

‚ÄúOur Teachers of the Year are inspirational leaders whose skill and passion make every child want to learn,‚Äù said Dr. Adrienne Battle, Director of Schools. ‚ÄúAn excellent teacher is a joy to behold. But even the very best teachers wouldn‚Äôt be as successful without great leadership from their principals, talented teacher colleagues, and strong backing from support employees, who deserve more recognition than they tend to get. Congratulations to all of this year‚Äôs winners and nominees and thank you for everything you do for our schools.‚Äù

#teacherappreciationweek2020 #thankateacher

‚ÄúThere is no replacement for being together and making music. Jatayvia‚Äôs words and the fact that thousands of students like her are going without the life-changing power of music in school right now is weighing on all of us in music education. All the cutting-edge apps, video lessons and recording platforms in the world are not going to change this, even though these tools and technologies can be engaging and useful. It‚Äôs just that teachers know there is no substitute for the real thing.‚Äù ‚Äî Sarah Robinson, strategic partnership coordinator for our district‚Äôs Music Makes Us program.
#MusicMakesUs #ArtsMoveMNPS

Congratulations to two Metro Schools graduates who were drafted by the NFL yesterday: Ke‚ÄôShawn Vaughn of Pearl-Cohn High School and Jacob Phillips of East Nashville Magnet High School.

Vaughn, a running back was drafted to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. He was the 76th picked for the third round of the draft.

Phillips was the 97th pick to the Cleveland Browns in the third round. Phillips, an inside linebacker, was a member of the Louisiana State University 2019 National Championship team.

Congratulations to Ke‚ÄôShawn and Jacob! üèà

And, here‚Äôs a 2019 story about the time the two MNPS stars met on the field as players for their colleges, LSU and Vanderbilt: https://hillsboroglobe.com/13029/sports/jacob-phillips-and-keshawn-vaughn-hume-nominees-are-this-weeks-featured-metro-boomin-athletes-to-watch/

It‚Äôs been six weeks since our children were in school together and if you are in need of ideas for helping a child navigate grief, we‚Äôve got resources and tips on the website today. And, if you want to share any of your own tips in the comments, please do. #inthistogether

post_text:
Families, thank you for your patience as our team delivers thousands of laptops to students. Great news: You can now request to reserve a laptop online for students in grades 5 to 12 (grades 3 to 12 starting April 27). You‚Äôll find the link in the ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù section of the digital tools page. We‚Äôll also add a direct link to the comments below.

And, if your student needs help resetting their MNPS email password, there are instructions on the digital tool page as well, but here it is too:

To reset your student email password, send an email to Student.PWresets@mnps.org and provide your:
- First Name
- Last Name
- Student ID number, starts with 190
- School Name

Yes, you can make this request from your personal or parental email account. And, this is an important step: Make sure you add Student.PWresets@mnps.org to contacts so our response doesn‚Äôt end up in your spam folder.

Thank you all for the support - and again, patience -- as we launch this new way of working and learning.
shared_text:
MNPS.ORG
Digital Tools ‚Äî Metro Nashville Public Schools
text:
Families, thank you for your patience as our team delivers thousands of laptops to students. Great news: You can now request to reserve a laptop online for students in grades 5 to 12 (grades 3 to 12 starting April 27). You‚Äôll find the link in the ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù section of the digital tools page. We‚Äôll also add a direct link to the comments below.

And, if your student needs help resetting their MNPS email password, there are instructions on the digital tool page as well, but here it is too:

To reset your student email password, send an email to Student.PWresets@mnps.org and provide your:
- First Name
- Last Name
- Student ID number, starts with 190
- School Name

Yes, you can make this request from your personal or parental email account. And, this is an important step: Make sure you add Student.PWresets@mnps.org to contacts so our response doesn‚Äôt end up in your spam folder.

Thank you all for the support - and again, patience -- as we launch this new way of working and learning.

MNPS.ORG
Digital Tools ‚Äî Metro Nashville Public Schools

post_text:
The Metro Schools Class of 2020 Valedictorians and Salutatorians are a diverse group of stars who look like the city they represent so well: 11 of them came into the district in the English Learners program; 22 have been MNPS students since kindergarten, and another eight started a little later in elementary school.

But they‚Äôll be remembered just as much as leaders of the first graduating class forced by a relentless virus to spend the last two months of its senior year at home ‚Äì and a class that managed its disappointment with grace, dignity and even creativity.

We present you the full list of 2020 Valedictorians and Salutatorians. Please send out a big cheer for them all.

https://www.mnps.org/blog/2020/4/20/2020-valedictorians-and-salutatorians

It is official: MNPS buildings will not reopen for the remainder of the school year. But, the teaching and learning will continue. Our district is launching structured, enhanced learning so every child has access to a high-quality education.

More information: https://bit.ly/MNPS_20192020

Seniors, we know what not being able to return to school means for you and we want you to know that decisions about graduation ceremonies and how best to celebrate and recognize the Class of 2020 will be made on, or before, May 1. Please bookmark: https://www.mnps.org/seniors

Breakfast and lunch pick-up meal service will continue through the remainder of the school year. Times and locations can be found at https://www.mnps.org/covid19

post_text:
Do you know that in Tennessee, everyone is a mandated reporter of suspected child abuse or neglect? And, right now, because children are not in school or in childcare, there are fewer teachers, childcare providers and other professionals who will be able to recognize and report abuse and neglect. Higher levels of stress impact family well-being and can potentially cause an increase in child abuse or neglect.

If you suspect a child is experiencing abuse or neglect, call the Tennessee Child Abuse Hotline:
877-237-0004. Reports also can be made online on the Tennessee Department of Children's Services secure and confidential site, http://tn.gov/reportchildabuse

April is National Child Abuse Prevention Month and you can find resources on the Children‚Äôs Bureau website: https://bit.ly/2K6ZTjJ.

#NCAPM2020

post_text:
This message is for Seniors in the Class of 2020: The State Department of Education has waived the 180-day school requirement and the State Board of Education has revised the graduation requirements.

What does this mean for you? If you had met the requirements for graduation on March 11, and pending a review of your records, you will be considered a graduate in the Class of 2020.

If you are a senior who still needs to complete credits to graduate, we are here to help you. Visit the https://www.mnps.org/seniors page for information.

For all seniors: Your school will be in touch with you by April 21 to give you details and instruction for your next steps.

Information from public health officials and the safety of students and families will inform decisions about graduation ceremonies.

For all other students, the district is operating under the plan that school is closed until at least April 24 and we will continue to share updates as we know them.

post_text:
Families and students, we want to acknowledge that isolation is hard. Missing our friends and colleagues is hard. If you, or someone you know, is in need of immediate assistance, or your life is in danger, call 9-1-1.

If you are in crisis, need help, or need someone to talk to, please call:
- National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255)
- The Crisis Center at 615-244-7444
- Text the Crisis Text Line at 741741
- Human Trafficking Hotline: 1-855-558-6484
- Report Child Abuse - Department of Children‚Äôs Services: 1-877-237-0004
- Sexual Assault Center 24 Hour Crisis Line: 1-800-879-1999

There is more information on https://www.mnps.org/family-support

post_text:
If you‚Äôre not getting district or school phone calls, check to make sure your phone and email are correct in the Family Portal: https://bit.ly/2JODSG4
If the information is correct and you want to opt back in to receive calls or texts, here are the instructions:
Telephone opt in: Call the Blackboard Phone Hotline at "855-502-STOP (855-502-7867)" from the phone line that has been opted out.
Opt in to Text (SMS) messages: Reply START to "60680" from the phone line that has been opted out messages. Reply START to "54968" for emergency messages.

PS: If you opted out, our staff cannot opt you in per the Telephone Consumer Protection Act.

post_text:
Seniors: The TN Promise mandatory webinar deadline is now May 15, 2020.

Any student whose mandatory meeting was scheduled after March 11, 2020 must watch the 37-minute webinar by 11:59 PM on May 15, 2020 to maintain TN Promise eligibility. Students who missed their assigned meeting prior to March 12, 2020 can view the webinar in order to reinstate TN Promise eligibility. Information: https://tnachieves.org/high-school-class-of-2020/cancellations

We have added this information, plus TN Achieves virtual community service information to the https://www.mnps.org/seniors page, as well.

#Classof2020

A month ago today, Nashville woke to tornado devastation. #TeamMNPS mobilized and did everything from feed to repair. And there's been no stop since. Now, each weekday, 100 nutrition services workers, bus drivers, staff and volunteers, led by our chief of operations, Ken Stark, provide meals to students across Nashville ‚Äî showing even more clearly just how vital Metro Schools‚Äô educators and staff are to our city. Read more and Ken and his team:
https://www.mnps.org/blog/2020/4/3/kenstarküíôüöåüöåüöå
#mnpsstrong

Nashville School of the Arts Senior Rachel Irwin wrote a parody of a popular song, telling us all a little bit about how she feels about the global pandemic upending her last year of high school:

‚ÄúYesterday, Corona wiped my senior year away‚ÄîNow at my house I have to stay ‚Äì Corona please go away
Suddenly, a global pandemic is on the scene, keep your hands and all surfaces clean, and if you‚Äôre sick, self-quarantine"

Metro Schools students, of all ages, we invite you to share with us the creativity, art, music, and more that you are making during this most unusual time. Learn how: https://www.mnps.org/blog/2020/4/2/students-show-and-tell

post_text:
A reminder for students who are unable to take the ACT this spring: Seniors who have not yet taken the ACT will not be required to do so in order to graduate.

The Tennessee Department of Education is working with ACT and anticipate offering additional testing dates.

At a minimum, juniors who are not able to test later this spring or summer will be able to use the October Senior Retake day. This option will be available for students who successfully tested in the spring or summer and students who will be testing for the first time in the fall.

This information and ACT study resources is on the website.

Good morning! Today is Census Day and our children need all of us to respond.

The vital programs and services your school district offers students - from meals to classroom technology to literacy and college prep to mental health services - depend on access to federal dollars. As of this morning, Davidson County had only a 32.9% response rate. Please take the #2020Census today:

- https://my2020census.gov - on your computer, on the phone, or mobile device
- call 844-330-2020 to respond by phone or request a paper questionnaire.

Daily reading enriches and rewards all of us. Director of Schools Adrienne Battle and Nashville Public Library Director Kent Oliver are encouraging students of all ages across Nashville to read at least 20-30 minutes a day as we all continue to practice social distancing.

Students, use your free Limitless Libraries access to read books and other resources online. And don‚Äôt just read; talk and write about what you‚Äôre reading. It‚Äôs a wonderful investment you can make in yourself day after day after day.

Here's the full letter: https://bit.ly/MNPSandNPL
And, if you are older than 13 and need a library card, here's the link to register for one: https://library.nashville.org/get-card

post_text:
Today we announce an exciting partnership with Nashville Public Television, which will offer 8 hours of ‚ÄúAt Home Learning‚Äù programming for children and students every weekday, 6 a.m.-2 p.m., while schools remain closed.

Starting Monday, March 30, NPT will air four hours for middle school and high school students from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. following its regular four-hour block of morning programming for younger children.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm extremely grateful for all NPT is doing to educate children and adults of all ages in a thoughtful, entertaining way,‚Äù Director of Schools Dr. Adrienne Battle said at Mayor John Cooper‚Äôs daily COVID-19 news briefing, where she was joined by NPT‚Äôs president and CEO, Kevin Crane.

Thank you, Nashville Public Television

For more resources for students, visit: https://www.mnps.org/digitaltools

post_text:
Following the guidance of Governor Bill Lee, schools will remain closed until at least April 24 to help contain the spread of COVID-19. We appreciate the patience of students, families and staff and will continue to communicate as often as we can.

Our staff will be reviewing recently announced guidance from the Tennessee Department of Education as we develop plans for the remainder of the school year.

‚ÄúThe safety and security of our students, staff, and families are paramount, and we appreciate Governor Lee following medical guidance and asking for schools to remain closed through April 24,‚Äù said Dr. Adrienne Battle, Director of Schools. ‚ÄúWhile our facilities will be closed, that doesn‚Äôt mean the work of education in Nashville stops. We‚Äôll be doing everything we can to engage and support our students and families, from meal offerings to educational enrichment activities over the next month.‚Äù

News release: http://news.mnps.org/metro-schools-facilities-to-remain-closed-through-april-24/

Bookmark our updates page: https://www.mnps.org/covid19

Community, your response to the 2020 Census is vital. The count impacts services our school district provides to all students, but it also specifically impacts special education, classroom technology and food assistance.
And, as you can see, our school district is hard at work supporting students and their families during unexpected events such as tornado recovery and pandemic.

Please fill out your 2020 Census. There‚Äôs information on our blog, flyers translated into several languages and links to information for students so they can learn why #EverybodyCounts.
Blog: https://bit.ly/2vJKWAA
Census Form Online: https://my2020census.gov

Flyers are in:
English, Arabic, Burmese, Kurdish, Somali and Spanish

#2020Census

Hey friends, how about some fun and energy expending and social distancing, all at the same time?

We can join in with others across the country to share art and inspiration on our sidewalks, driveways or at a park close to home. Send a message to your teachers, your neighbors, and all the people who are working hard to keep our community safe.

If you #ChalkYourWalk this weekend, share the photos here, or tag us @MetroSchools on Twitter and Instagram. Use the hashtag #mnpsstrong.

Just remember to keep a safe distance from others and keep washing your hands. üåà‚ù§Ô∏è

post_text:
Beginning Monday, Metro Schools bus drivers will deliver meals to children in several Nashville neighborhoods. Additionally, MNPS will offer meals-to-go for children at several school locations.

‚ÄúWe know that many of our families won‚Äôt have access to the transportation necessary to get to one of our school-based distribution locations, so we‚Äôre doing our best to get out into the community and get food to the kids who need it the most,‚Äù said Dr. Adrienne Battle, Director of Schools.

Locations and times for bus driver deliveries will be added to https://www.mnps.org/covid19 when they become available, as well as shared with MNPS families through social media and callouts.

Full details and a revised meal pick-up schedule: http://news.mnps.org/mnps-to-offer-student-meal-delivery-in-select-areas-of-nashville/

Metro Nashville Public Schools will be offering free student meals along with food boxes at several locations throughout Davidson County.

- Wednesday, March 18: Food boxes will be available at several school locations, as long as supplies last. The food boxes are provided by Second Harvest Food Bank and food bags are provided by The Bridge Ministry.

- Beginning Monday, March 23: Metro Schools offer free weekday breakfast and lunch meals to children in Nashville at school locations throughout Davidson County. The meals will be bagged or boxed and available in a drive-through setup.

Locations and details: https://news.mnps.org/mnps-food-delivery-sites-announced/

- Food distribution for families
- Grab-and-go lunches for students
- Closing of district offices and facilities to the public

We will provide updates on our Metro Schools social media channels and website: mnps.org/health

Link to news release: http://news.mnps.org/metro-schools-closed-through-april-3/
text:
Metro Nashville Public Schools will be closed at least through April 3, 2020, in response to the public health emergency caused by the spread of COVID-19.

Please read our release for information on:
- Third-quarter grading and assessments
- Food distribution for families
- Grab-and-go lunches for students
- Closing of district offices and facilities to the public

We will provide updates on our Metro Schools social media channels and website: mnps.org/health

Link to news release: http://news.mnps.org/metro-schools-closed-through-april-3/

post_text:
Metro Schools district offices will be closed from Monday, March 16 to Friday, March 20. Central office staff and school-based 12-month employees will work remotely to ensure our critical functions, such as payroll, budgeting and food delivery still can occur.

The Family Information Center will be available primarily by email: familyinfo@mnps.org

‚ÄúPracticing social distancing this week, which is spring break for all MNPS students, will help prevent the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus. It‚Äôs important that we do our part as an organization during this extremely challenging time for our city, state and nation.‚Äô‚Äô ‚Äî MNPS Superintendent Adrienne Battle.

We will continue to post updates on our health page: www.mnps.org/health

post_text:
MNPS juniors will take the ACT at school on
March 31st. This test is important: A composite score of 21 on the ACT is a minimum qualification for the Tennessee HOPE Scholarship, which can save families up to $16,000 at a four-year college or university and higher scores can translate to even more cost savings at many postsecondary institutions across the country.

Learn more https://www.mnps.org/act

Today's resource:
Prepare to take the ACT, http://bit.ly/2TOeK72

Metro Schools will be closed Thursday and Friday, March 5 and 6. Please read our release for details and for important information for district staff and 12-month employees. Details: http://bit.ly/2TmVkXN

‚ÄúNashvillians have experienced a traumatic event and we know it will take time to heal,‚Äù said interim director of schools Dr. Adrienne Battle. ‚ÄúClosing the rest of the week will allow time for that healing process, allow our staff and students to volunteer in the community, and give our district a chance to prepare our facilities for normal operation starting on Monday.‚Äù
text:
Metro Schools will be closed Thursday and Friday, March 5 and 6. Please read our release for details and for important information for district staff and 12-month employees. Details: http://bit.ly/2TmVkXN

‚ÄúNashvillians have experienced a traumatic event and we know it will take time to heal,‚Äù said interim director of schools Dr. Adrienne Battle. ‚ÄúClosing the rest of the week will allow time for that healing process, allow our staff and students to volunteer in the community, and give our district a chance to prepare our facilities for normal operation starting on Monday.‚Äù

post_text:
As we process, recover and rebuild, some tips for talking to our children about what has happened:

"Much like adults, children find comfort in routines and regularity. When these are threatened by unpredictable and uncontrollable natural disasters, like hurricanes, a child‚Äôs first concern is often about his or her own safety ‚Äì even when the actual disaster may be a world away. But, when given opportunities to talk about the event and process their feelings in familiar ways, even young children can manage and cope with the stress of a natural disaster."

#nashvillestrong #nashvilletornado
shared_text:
MYSOUTHERNHEALTH.COM
How to help children understand natural disasters | My Southern Health

#PublicSchoolsWeek Serving our students happens with teamwork and in community. Here are just a few of the folks who keep our schools running every single day and one picture that speaks to the why we do it.

We are: Teachers, nutrition staff, bus drivers, translators, counselors, coaches, crossing guards, para-professionals, facilities staff, administrative staff, volunteers, librarians, exceptional education teachers, substitute teachers. nurses, teachers who are scientists, musicians, writers, dancers, plus technology professionals, data analysts, security staff, grants managers, resource coordinators, speech therapists, parents, community partners, neighborhood groups, volunteers - and so many more vital contributors.

Thank you to all. And, have a good weekend.
#MNPSProud.
photo: MNPS Eagle View Elementary School

post_text:
Fifty-seven students from 11 STEAM middle schools participated in the Invention Convention hosted at the Adventure Science Center this week, where students were challenged to share their innovative ideas for improving the world around them.
Students presented ideas for removing invasive species from waterways, chairs made from sustainable products, methods to encourage recycling, a transit plan for Nashville, devices to make household chores more efficient, among other things.
Martin Luther King, Jr. Magnet senior Mert Sekman spoke to students about his testing ideas for pneumonia, Hillwood High School senior Katherine Wright spoke about her how she developed an affordable solar oven to be used in less economically developed countries, and middle school student Therese Boling, who created Let‚Äôs Run Kids, a shoe drive inspired by the book ‚ÄúGhost‚Äù by Jason Reynolds.

The creativity and passion of all students was inspiring. It was a fantastic event and could not have occurred without the support of Adventure Science Center and our many wonderful volunteers.
text:
Fifty-seven students from 11 STEAM middle schools participated in the Invention Convention hosted at the Adventure Science Center this week, where students were challenged to share their innovative ideas for improving the world around them.
Students presented ideas for removing invasive species from waterways, chairs made from sustainable products, methods to encourage recycling, a transit plan for Nashville, devices to make household chores more efficient, among other things.
Martin Luther King, Jr. Magnet senior Mert Sekman spoke to students about his testing ideas for pneumonia, Hillwood High School senior Katherine Wright spoke about her how she developed an affordable solar oven to be used in less economically developed countries, and middle school student Therese Boling, who created Let‚Äôs Run Kids, a shoe drive inspired by the book ‚ÄúGhost‚Äù by Jason Reynolds.

The creativity and passion of all students was inspiring. It was a fantastic event and could not have occurred without the support of Adventure Science Center and our many wonderful volunteers.

Croft Middle School 8th grade teacher Anna Levy, who works with English Language Learners, has received national recognition for her work.
‚ÄúAll the world sits in my classroom somedays,‚Äù Levy shared. ‚ÄúI watch my students play soccer at recess and I have to marvel at the fact that there are students from all over the world and here they are playing soccer together. If that‚Äôs not powerful, then I don‚Äôt know what is.‚Äù
Thank you, and Congratulations, Ms. Levy! üåé

Story: https://wida.wisc.edu/about/news/february-2020-featured-educator-anna-levy

Nashville Public Library has put together a list of new picture books for Black History Month, and is holding free events at various branches to celebrate Black History Month. They include:
- Youth break dance workshop, 3 p.m. Feb 12, Bordeaux branch, 4000 Clarksville Pike. For ages 6-12.
- Art workshop, Bellevue branch, 720 Baugh Road, 4 p.m. Feb. 18 for students kindergarten through 4th grade to create art pieces with reused materials in the style of artist Alma Thomas, whose work is in the permanent collection at the White House.
- Southeast branch, 5260 Hickory Hollow Parkway: "African American History Month Through the Lens of Toni Morrison‚Äôs 'Beloved'" at 5:30 p.m. Feb. 27. For adults.
- The Old Hickory branch, 1010 Jones Street: ‚ÄùFresh Freedom: Freedom Song Analysis" at 4:30 p.m. Feb. 13. For grades K-8. Listen to songs about freedom from the Library‚Äôs Civil Rights Collection and create and sing their own freedom song.

LIBRARY.NASHVILLE.ORG

METRO NASHVILLE SCHOOLS CLOSED ON FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 2020

Metro Nashville Public Schools will be closed on Friday, February 7 due to anticipated inclement weather, as well as projected student and teacher absences due to illness. Before and after care programs will be closed. All after-school activities are canceled as well, including sports practice, games, performances, parent meetings, etc.

District offices will remain open and all 12-month employees will report as normal, but we urge individuals to use their best discretion based on their individual situations.

YMCA Fun Company will operate inclement weather sites at the following schools:
Hattie Cotton- 1033 W Greenwood Ave
Harpeth Valley- 2840 Learning Ln
Norman Binkley- 4700 W Longdale Dr
KIPP Antioch- 3655 Murfreesboro Pike
Tulip Grove- 441 Tyler Drive

You also are welcome to contact our team at communications@mnps.org to share suggestions, memories and photos.

post_text:
Families of Pre-K students: Do you want your child to stay in the same school for Kindergarten? Here‚Äôs how:

If the school is a choice school, and out of your zone, you must apply for a seat there using the School Options application before Feb. 14.
Once you accept your seat, enroll your student for Kindergarten at an Enrollment Center.
*This excludes Stanford and Hull Jackson students.

If another language, besides English is spoken in your home, please call the Office of English Learners to make an appointment to register at (615) 259-8608.

If you plan to enroll in your zoned school, register at an MNPS Enrollment Center, on or after, Feb. 10.

Questions? Email familyinfo@mnps.org
Enrollment information: https://www.mnps.org/register-for-school

Inglewood Elementary, a STEAM Magnet school, is celebrating its 90th Birthday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturday, January 25. The community is invited to the special event, which includes a puppet show by the Nashville Public Library. It also is a great opportunity for families and potential students to tour the school, meet the staff and learn more about all that Inglewood offers.

In this interview, which includes a fun video, Inglewood Principal Ashley Croft tells us more about herself, her focus at the school and tight-knit community she and the staff are building and strengthening.

Inglewood Elementary School - an Environmental Sciences STEAM Magnet

The Blue Ribbon Teacher Award recognizes excellence in teaching throughout Metro Nashville Public Schools.
The award, in collaboration with the Nashville Public Education Foundation and community partners - will identify up to 50 extraordinary teachers to receive a $1,000 award.
Application deadline is this Friday, January 24. Apply today: www.mnps.org/blue-ribbon-teacher

post_text:
More than 800 Metro Schools high school students saw Hamilton yesterday at the Tennessee Performing Arts Center ‚Äì and several powerfully performed original music & creative pieces inspired by the musical, plus they had a great question and answer session with the cast & crew.

Thanks to the Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History for making this tremendous opportunity possible for students.

*We got this great photo from Jared Dixon‚Äôs Instagram. He plays Burr in the musical.

Our participating schools: Antioch
Cane Ridge, East, Glencliff, Hillsboro, Hunters Lane, McGavock, Overton, Pearl-Cohn plus KIPP Nashville Collegiate and LEAD Academy High School.
MNPS Visual and Performing Arts #EduHam

"I am not throwing away my shot..."

Students: Learn about selective college admission and affordability at a free event open to all area students.
Admissions representatives from Case Western Reserve University, Emory University, University of California Los Angeles, and Yale University will be present to answer questions and offer insights - and not just about their own college admissions process.
When and Where: ‚Ä®6:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. Thursday, January 30 in the Harlin Student Center of Battle Ground Academy, 336 Ernest Rice Lane, Franklin.
Register online and you will receive more information about the event and parking. Registration link: http://bit.ly/30rCHUB
* Due to space limitations, event organizers ask that just one parent or guardian attend with their student.

Battle Ground Academy

post_text: Congratulations to East Nashville High School alumnus, Jacob Phillips, and LSU Football on winning the 2020 National Football Championship against Clemson University. Phillips, a starting linebacker, had eight tackles during the Jan. 13 football game, totaling 113 for the entire season. He was named a 2017 Army All-American.

post_text:
Congratulations to Martin Luther King Jr. Magnet student, Mert Sekmen, for earning a spot in the top 300 scholars for the Regeneron Science Talent Search- a prestigious science and math competition for seniors. Sekmen is also a part of the School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt program.

The Regeneron Talent Search provides students a national stage to present original research. The scholars were selected from 1,993 applications received from 659 high schools across 49 states. See the complete list of winners here: http://bit.ly/307r2do

post_text:
Want to avoid the lines during the initial Pre-K application period? Get ahead and visit any of our eight enrollment centers at any time to get your student's identification number (required for application). Then on March 2, you will be ready to submit your Pre-K application online! Find a list of documents needed and enrollment centers here: www.mnps.org/register-for-school.

Other important dates:
Kindergarten Registration Kick-Off -- Feb. 10
Kindergarten Readiness Fair -- March 28

post_text:
MNPS staff and members of the community we seek your input on potential new instructional materials, including new student materials, workbooks, teacher materials, etc.

All materials, approved by the Tennessee Department of Education for consideration, will be available for review from January 21 to 31 at the MNEA building, 531 Fairground Court. Hours: are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. each day. Extended hours will be 9 to 7 p.m. January 27 and until 6:30 p.m. January 28

Teacher supply bags, provided by PENCIL, will be available to staff.

The selection committee, made up of MNPS teachers, will make recommendations to the School Board in the Spring.

Thank you in advance!

post_text:
Nearly 50 Metro Schools teachers from across the county ‚Äì each of them the Teacher of the Year at his or her school ‚Äì came together Monday evening for the first meeting of Interim Director of Schools Adrienne Battle‚Äôs Teachers Cabinet.
Dr. Battle shared school climate survey data with the teachers and asked them to discuss discipline challenges and potential solutions at the elementary, middle and high school levels. Dr. Battle and her team plan to study the comments and implement solutions wherever possible. One veteran teacher said she hadn‚Äôt been heard like this until now.
Dr. Battle plans to hold meetings of the Director‚Äôs Teachers Cabinet at least once a quarter. Teachers of the Year from schools throughout the district are eligible to participate.
text:
Nearly 50 Metro Schools teachers from across the county ‚Äì each of them the Teacher of the Year at his or her school ‚Äì came together Monday evening for the first meeting of Interim Director of Schools Adrienne Battle‚Äôs Teachers Cabinet.
Dr. Battle shared school climate survey data with the teachers and asked them to discuss discipline challenges and potential solutions at the elementary, middle and high school levels. Dr. Battle and her team plan to study the comments and implement solutions wherever possible. One veteran teacher said she hadn‚Äôt been heard like this until now.
Dr. Battle plans to hold meetings of the Director‚Äôs Teachers Cabinet at least once a quarter. Teachers of the Year from schools throughout the district are eligible to participate.

post_text:
Four Metro Schools poets will be showcased at the State of the Word poetry event on Friday, Dec. 13. One will be chosen to serve as the sixth Nashville Youth Poet Laureate. The finalists are:

* Alora Young, Hillsboro High School
* Sumaya Muhamed, Martin Luther King Jr. Academic Magnet
* Charlotte Edwards, Hume Fogg Academic Magnet
* Ephie Hauck, John Overton High School

Good luck to all! And thank you for sharing your insight and passions.

The event is at 7:30 p.m. at Vanderbilt's Blair School of Music. Tickets, $10 general admission and $3 for students, are available at www.southernword.org.

post_text:
Pearl-Cohn High School held a celebratory send-off for its Firebirds football team today as they head to the State Championship game tomorrow!

Do you see Coach Tony Brunetti in there in the middle of the team? Not only is he leading the Firebirds to the State Championship but he is one of nine Tennessee coaches in the running for Tennessee Titans Coach of the Year. ÔøΩÔøΩThe award honors head coaches in Tennessee who ‚Äúcontinuously demonstrate excellence in their profession, dedication to their football programs and focus on the safety and character of their players.‚Äù

The winner will be announced following the 2019 BlueCross Bowl state championship games. The winner will also earn a $2,000 grant for their school‚Äôs football program, an all-expense paid trip to the 2020 NFL Pro Bowl in Orlando and the will automatically be in the running for the Don Shula NFL High School Coach of the Year award.
Congratulations Coach Brunetti on being selected as a finalist for this award.

post_text:
We're talking a lot of high school football this week. Why? Because our players are awesome and Pearl-Cohn is headed to the state championship.

At Friday's TSSAA Bluecross Bowl Championship, keep an eye out for these Pearl-Cohn High Firebirds, who are the state‚Äôs top college recruits for football. They include:
* Kyndrich Breedlove, Centerback - The three-star Firebird standout has a three-star ranking as the No. 24 prospect in the state. He has offers from Louisville, Kentucky, Virginia Tech, Tennessee, Texas A&M, Auburn, LSU and Missouri.
* William Griffin, Offensive tackle - The No. 12 prospect in the state, Griffin is a three-star lineman. He has offers from Alabama, Ohio State, Tennessee, Vanderbilt, Kentucky, Auburn, Georgia, LSU and Oklahoma.
* Barion Brown, Around the House - Brown has an offer from Tennessee. He has 32 receptions for 545 yards and 10 touchdowns this season.

Let‚Äôs Go Firebirds!

Today for American Education Week 2019, we celebrate the importance of parental and family involvement. Emily Hawarah, whose daughter Kate is a sophomore at Nashville School of the Arts, tells us why she volunteers:

‚ÄúI volunteer at my daughter‚Äôs high school because it allows me to share in her experiences and learn incredible things from her and her peers. I truly believe that this generation is going to radically change the world, and I feel honored to get a first-hand view as they learn, grow and figure out how to shape their communities in the future,‚Äô‚Äô said Emily, who volunteers in Kate‚Äôs choral conservatory and with the school organization, Friends of NSA.

#AEW2019

Shayne Elementary special education teacher Robert E. Hawkins, has published a book entitled "Book of Matches," which is about his Appalachian family, his grandfather‚Äôs murder and his grandmother‚Äôs grit.
‚ÄúI have done plenty of things I have been proud of, but the people on the pages of that book I am most proud of,‚Äô‚Äô said Hawkins, who also is a music producer, singer-songwriter, independent recording artist, and guitarist.
The book has been released in conjunction with the Jesse Stuart Foundation and is available on robhawkins.com

Donelson Middle was among the dozens of Metro Public Schools that hosted PENCIL Principal for a Day community members yesterday. Here's what Principal Jennifer Rheinecker said about why it is great when community members visit our schools:
‚ÄúYou can only learn so much about what happens in a school from outside the school. What you see in the media and what you see in passing is only a small piece of what happens inside of our schools.
‚ÄúThe best way to see and know what happens and how amazing our kids are is to come in and see them in action‚Äîand you will really see the great things that our kids and teachers are doing each and every day.‚Äú

October 26, 2019 at 7:07 AM ¬∑

Important Date: November 1 is the deadline to apply for the TNPromise scholarship for the Class of 2020.

The scholarship will cover the cost of tuition and mandatory fees that are not covered by the Pell grant, the HOPE scholarship, or the Tennessee Student Assistance Award.

Students may use the scholarship at any of the state‚Äôs 13 community colleges, 27 colleges of applied technology, or other eligible institution offering an associate degree program.
Application and information at: https://www.tnpromise.gov/

post_text:
Catherine Knowles, MNPS HERO coordinator, has been named Homeless Liaison of the Year by the National Association for the Education of Homeless Children and Youth.

She is tireless and dedicated and makes a huge difference in the lives of so many students and their families.

"Every year there are more than 3,000 students experiencing homelessness enrolled in our district. These students and their families face many challenges yet they are incredibly resilient. The HERO Program and its community partners work diligently to offer support during this time of transition,'' she said.

Details: https://bit.ly/2BRAmHe

post_text:
You are not seeing double in this photo - it's triple! Metro Nashville Virtual Academy triplets Ahmed, Fatimah and Zaynab Alnassar will be dual enrolling at Middle Tennessee State University in the fall of 2020. The triplets, and their mom Khaeijah, will all be freshmen at the university, marking a first for the freshmen class at Middle Tennessee State.

The Alnassar triplets are also artists and have received multiple awards at the Tennessee State Fair. Their artwork and craft have also been on display at the LaVergne Public Library and each triplet is a published author.

Arianna Smith, a senior at Hume-Fogg Academic High School, also attended the MTSU True Blue Tour and received a $6,000 scholarship. The honors students will be studying under the university‚Äôs Department of Physics and Astronomy in the fall.

Details in the story linked.

Martin Luther King Jr. Magnet High School student and Pearl-Cohn High School football player Wesley Schelling has verbally committed to play for Vanderbilt University. The future Commodore is the fifth ranked long snapper in the country.

Schelling maintains 4.0 grade point average (unweighted) in his advanced placement and honors courses at Martin Luther King Jr. Magnet. He is also a recipient of the 2019 Swarthmore College Book Award, a member of the National Honor Society and will attend the university on a full football scholarship. Congratulations Wesley! üèà

post_text:
Metro Nashville Public Schools and the Metro Nashville Police Department were recognized at the National Handle with Care Conference in Charleston, West Virginia for their on-going efforts to support and help children exposed and impacted by traumatic events.

Each day, police staff alert our schools when a student has experienced a potentially traumatic event in the community so our school staff can offer support and services to help our students heal and thrive.

Congratulations and thank you to our staff and the MNPD for making a lasting impact in the lives of our students and their families.

For more on the wide range of programs and services we offer in our schools, please visit the family support page on our website: https://www.mnps.org/family-support

post_text:
Here's a cool program: Metro Nashville Public Schools students are participating in the HBCU C2 (Code and Create) partnership with Tennessee State University as part of Apple Inc.‚Äôs Community Education Initiative, which is focused on bringing coding skills to students in underserved communities.

MNPS is the only K-12 public school system to introduce this type of learning experience with the multinational tech company and historically black university.

The program will pilot in one of the district‚Äôs schools and eventually expand to a total of six MNPS schools. Apple developed the curriculum and will provide all devices for student-use. Students will learn how to write code and design apps, with an opportunity to have their apps available to thousands of consumers through the Apple Store. The program will also offer students an opportunity to earn three credit toward a college degree and to sit for an industry certification exam. üçé

Apple Tennessee State University

post_text: Career Fair is this Saturday from 8 to 2 p.m. Join us to learn more about joining #TEAMMNPS.
shared_text:
Metro Schools Human Resources and Organizational Development
October 1, 2019 at 8:52 AM ¬∑

Have you ever seen yourself in the classroom, but you don't know where to start?

We're looking for individuals to join Team MNPS as para-professionals. Our para-professionals are benefits-eligible and receive professional development training, all while learning the ins and outs of teaching.

Learn more at our Career Fair on Oct. 5. at our MNPS Wellness Center, 2694 Fessey Court in Berry Hill.

post_text:
The students at Hull-Jackson Montessori got great lessons on trees and photosynthesis, plus they wrote "poetree" and ran "treelays" with cyclists who were participating in the five-day Tour des Trees and riding to raise awareness for the TREE Fund.

Thanks for Root Nashville for helping to make this learning happen. üå≥ üö¥üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüå≥ üö¥üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è üå≥
shared_text:
Root Nashville
September 20, 2019 at 6:09 PM ¬∑

Incredible afternoon with Hull-Jackson Montessori and the Tour des Trees riders of the TREE Fund! After a weeklong ride, the cyclists ended their tour at Hull-Jackson for a celebration with the students and Root Nashville, full of learning and activities for the students. We wrote "poetree," raced in a "treelay," learned about photosynthesis from rider Professor Pricklethorn, observed the natural habitat with a biodiversity scavenger hunt... and in general, loved on trees! Thanks to our friends and partners Nashville Tree Foundation for joining in on the fun.
