Congratulations to Martin Luther King Jr. Magnet High School student Sydney Bayless on being selected to perform in the Nashville Ballet‚Äôs performance of Romeo and Juliet. She's dancing tonight and through Sunday!

Bayless, a 9th grader, has been dancing for three years and was selected, without auditioning, for the William Shakespeare classic. She will make her performance debut at the Tennessee Performance Arts Center‚Äôs Jackson Hall Friday, September 20 through Sunday, September 22.

For more information or tickets, visit https://www.nashvilleballet.com/romeo-and-juliet. (And see Sydney's photo in the comments)

post_text:
Hispanic Heritage Month is celebrated from September 15 to October 15 and recognizes the contributions of Americans of Hispanic and Latino descent.

Visit https://www.hispanicheritagemonth.gov/for-teachers/ for great resources - from videos to lesson plans to free streaming music - on this collaborative website created by government agencies such as the Library of Congress, the National Endowment for the Humanities, National Gallery of Art, National Park Service and the Smithsonian Institution.

post_text:
This is National Arts in Education Week, a national celebration recognizing the power of arts in education. üé≠üé®üé§ü•Åüìñ

If you‚Äôve ever seen our students perform in marching band, or in plays, viewed their art, heard their poetry, you know we are so very proud of their creativity and hard work. Our district is dedicated to providing every student access to arts education opportunities. Thanks to our outstanding educators for their work in transforming the lives of our students through music, visual art, theatre, and dance.

You can read and share about arts education by using the national hashtag #BecauseOfArtsEd and also tagging our MNPS hashtags #ArtsMoveMNPS and #MusicMakesUs.

Imagines: McGavock HS production of Hairspray; "Head Over Heels" by Hume-Fogg student SK Steen; Oliver Middle's production of Sound of Music; Art Teacher Angela Naglieri; Stratford Marching Band.

Music Makes Us

post_text:
There is a lot to celebrate as newly released #TNReady results show the district moved up in overall status, Metro Schools students made strides in math and literacy and 37 schools are on the Reward List - an increase of 15.

‚ÄúHere is what I told our principals and staff over the summer: Know where you are, but don‚Äôt stay there," MNPS Interim Director of Schools Dr. Adrienne Battle said. ‚ÄúStudents are at the center of everything the district does, and we will use the data to improve our practices and instruction. We will make progress by building on our strengths.‚Äù

Read more takeaways in the story linked here. And, in the coming weeks, data analysts will work with principals to understand their school‚Äôs results.

(Pictured is the Nashville School of the Arts, Night on Broadway performance, 2019)

post_text:
Families and students, a word on transportation: Thank you for your patience in these early days of the new school year. Some buses have run behind as drivers learn routes and in the first couple of weeks, it may take longer to get going because drivers are speaking to students to make sure they're on the right bus, and exiting at the right location. And, it does take students a bit longer to get on and off the bus in the first days of school. We also are hiring more bus drivers. It will all speed up soon.

If you have questions, please contact the Family Information Center (615) 259-INFO or
FamilyInfo@mnps.org

Website: https://www.mnps.org/transportation

Again, thank you for your feedback, understanding and patience. We are happy to support your family with transportation to and from Metro Schools.

post_text: Congratulations to the Rose Park Middle School Technology Student Association team. At Nationals, several of the team members advanced to become semifinalists or national winners! Placing at Nationals is a first for Rose Park TSA students.
shared_text:
Rose Park PTSO
August 1, 2019 at 1:35 PM ¬∑

Become a member of the Rose Park TSA (Technology Student Association) team. TSA was very successful at Nationals, as several team members advanced to become semifinalists or national winners! Placing at Nationals is a first for Rose Park TSA students. So proud of our students!

Members of the TSA team that went to Nationals are from left to right: Kez Echols, Klaudia Hunter, Lucy Cullum, Zofia Hunter, Megan Schelling, Jake Wilder, Jonas Cross, and Walt Ostrowski. Also pictured below are team members Lena Feleke, Bethel Sammy, and James Roberts

New Glencliff High School students learned about their academy options on the First Day of School this week.

Through their academy, students are exposed to a multitude of career and college opportunities, industry skills, and potential employers by way of classroom speakers, site visits, job shadowing and internships. Students have their choice of more than 39 different academies within the 12 largest neighborhood high schools in MNPS.

To learn more about the Academies of Nashville, please visit: https://bit.ly/2YPU92S
